Donate Group 2 Protect Conservation in action Partner Help the Zoo make a difference Donate Group 3 Internship Opportunities Adopt an Animal Message from an Animal Volunteer Opportunities Tickets Donate √ó \ Central Florida Zoo & Botanical Gardens ‚Ä∫ News ‚Ä∫ Conservation expert Dr. Laurie Marker visits the Central Florida Zoo & Botanical Gardens for a ‚ÄúCheetah Chat‚Äù Conservation expert Dr. Laurie Marker visits the Central Florida Zoo & Botanical Gardens for a ‚ÄúCheetah Chat‚Äù Thursday, April 20, 2023 Conservation expert Dr. Laurie Marker visits the Central Florida Zoo & Botanical Gardens for a ‚ÄúCheetah Chat‚Äù On Monday, April 17, the Central Florida Zoo & Botanical Gardens had a truly remarkable opportunity. We hosted Dr. Laurie Marker, F ounder and Executive Director of the Cheetah Conservation Fund . An expert in her field, she has been working closely with the breeding and reintroduction of cheetahs for nearly 50 years, including building the CCF in 1990. After a tour of the facilities and an up-close introduction to the Zoo‚Äôs own handsome cheetah brothers Cheeto and Frito , Dr. Marker lent some of her expertise and insight to the carnivore keeper team, covering a range of topics from behaviors and nutrition to genetics and habitat. In the evening, Dr. Marker gave a presentation on cheetah conservation to guests and VIPs, tracing her journey from winery and goat farm owner to managing hundreds of thousands of acres of land devoted to cheetah conservation in both Namibia and Somaliland. Cheetah populations once hovered around 100,000 in the year 1900, dropping significantly over the century to less than 7,100 animals today. Now extinct in over 20 countries where they once lived, these beautiful and unique cats still need our help. ‚ÄúEducation is key‚Äù, she emphasized, sharing stories about developing laws in the Middle East to prevent illegal wildlife trade that puts wild cheetahs at risk. From teaching African farmers not to kill these animals out of fear to introducing the concept that wildlife is an important part of people‚Äôs lives, she‚Äôs been spreading awareness on a human level. The CCF in Namibia has also done incredible work with habitat restoration, developing systems that clear wild thornbush from overgrown and unusable¬† land, as well as a program that introduces livestock guard dogs to local farmers in order to deter the old ‚Äúkill on sight‚Äù policy when it comes to these natural wild predators. Their facility in Namibia has also performed critical research for reproduction, stating that ‚ÄòThere is hope!‚Äô when it comes to cheetah conservation and repopulation. Tracking genetic traits among cheetahs in zoos, Dr. Marker has worked closely with the AZA SAFE: Saving Animals From Extinction program to create cheetah studbooks to promote genetic diversity. ‚ÄúYour own Zoo cheetahs may someday be part of the saving grace of cheetahs living in the wild,‚Äù she said. We at the Central Florida Zoo & Botanical Gardens were honored to host Dr. Marker. It was, as one of our animal team leaders says, a career highlight of a day. And you, too, can make a difference! If you‚Äôd like to help, visit http://www.cheetah.org to donate, volunteer, or simply spread awareness about cheetah conservation. We know Cheeto and Frito will also be waiting on your visit! Teens will receive special hands-on training, including educating the public about conservation, presenting wildlife biofacts, and handling animals. They‚Äôll participate in special events and share their new knowledge on wildlife and conservation issues with guests, learning the skills they‚Äôll need later in life and gaining valuable work experience. Duties Educate members of the public of all ages Facilitate learning opportunities Animal handling, interpretation, and observations Utilize bio-facts to educate guests Educate the public about animal conservation at Zoo events Assist with zoo projects Monitor guest interactions and enforce Zoo policies to keep animals and guests safe How to Apply ‚ÄãWe bring on new Teen Team volunteers once a year. The annual process starts in February when we open applications, where applications remain open for two months.¬†You will be able to complete the application using the link below at that time. Three required documents need to be attached to the application, and those documents will be available on the application when it opens. How it Works Teens must apply for the Teen Team program and complete an interview on a pre-scheduled interview date. If selected, teens must attend a multi-day training program and pass a final exam. Training classes will be during the summer, on the weekends. Upon successful completion of training, teens volunteer on select Saturdays and Sundays each month. During Summer break, teens may have the opportunity to volunteer on weekdays by assisting with Summer Camp. For Parents & Guardians The Teen Team program is designed to foster independence, professionalism, and responsibility in teens. Our program is designed to provide a healthy boost to teens‚Äô self-confidence,¬†self-esteem, and life satisfaction.¬†While parental support is important, it‚Äôs crucial that teens take the initiative in managing their volunteer commitments just as they would in a paid position. This means they should be the primary contact for communications and be proactive in handling their schedules and responsibilities. Please encourage your teen to fill out the application themselves, have them use their own email and phone number in the application, and encourage them to communicate directly with Volunteer Services staff. This experience is not only about volunteering but also about growing into responsible, professional, and self-sufficient young adults. Important Dates The application and onboarding process is as follows: February ‚Äì Applications Open April ‚Äì Applications Close & Interview Invites Are Sent Out May ‚Äì Selected Applicants Will Interview June ‚Äì Training Begins Requirements Must be between ages 13-17 years old at the start of the program in June. Accepted teens who turn 18 years old during the program and are finishing out their senior year are permitted to stay in the program through the end of their graduating summer. After that, they will have aged out from the program and are eligible for our adult volunteer programs. Pass training program with 80% or higher. Pay a $35 tuition fee for onboarding materials and uniform. If this fee creates a financial hardship, please contact us for assistance. Must be able to commit to volunteering 30 hours annually. Able to complete volunteer shifts during Zoo operating hours. Participate in volunteer orientation and training. Successfully completed introductory period. Abide by policies in the Volunteer Handbook. Provide excellent customer service and demonstrate the ability to work well with visitors. Must successfully pass a background check. Must be able to tolerate Florida‚Äôs weather conditions. Be interested in educating the public about conservation. Apply Now Questions? Media Contacts Please send all media and digital requests to: press@centralfloridazoo.org Please send all marketing and paid advertising requests to: marketing@centralfloridazoo.org Media Policy View the Zoo‚Äôs Privacy and Copyright policy regarding images, documents, etc. All media inquiries should be directed to the Zoo‚Äôs Communications team. Photos taken for private, personal use are welcome. Taking photos or video for commercial purposes, including stock images, commercial products or purposes is strictly prohibited. Complimentary admission can be arranged for media professionals. The more lead time we have, the more available opportunities we may have. Media requests, if approved, are only available during off-peak days and times. Credentials are required for those visiting for media events. We will request links or copies of all published articles, photographs, or videos. Behind-the-scenes coverage is prohibited unless otherwise arranged in advance. All imaging equipment must remain in public areas and not cross into animal habitats. If you‚Äôd like to take photos or film at the Central Florida Zoo & Botanical Gardens for any reason besides personal use, you must submit a request in writing to the Zoo‚Äôs Communications team in advance with the following information: Individual or company name, phone number, and e-mail address Explain the purpose of your project If an interview is requested, please provide the detailed questions so we can arrange the appropriate representative The number of people involved in the shoot List of the number and types of equipment being used Request for particular animals Include the area of the Zoo you‚Äôd like to shoot Any additional details the Central Florida Zoo & Botanical Gardens should be aware of We reserve the right to deny and request or cancel any shoot if at any time it is not in the best interest of the animals, visitors, or does not align with the Zoo‚Äôs mission. Members of the Press & Media The Central Florida Zoo & Botanical Gardens‚Äô policy requires all media requests to be screened by our communications department. For breaking news or developing stories, media representatives are asked to contact 407-323-4450 ext. 106 to schedule filming opportunities and interviews. To be added to our press release contact list, please send a request to communications@centralfloridazoo.org . We understand the nature of minute-by-minute news and will try to accommodate all stations as possible. Commercial Filming & Photography Permission is required for all photo and video obtained for commercial purposes on Central Florida Zoo & Botanical Gardens‚Äô grounds. This includes all property past the front entrance off of West Seminole Boulevard including, but not limited to‚Äîthe train, Seminole Aerial Adventures, Wayne M. Densch Discovery Center, and the entirety of the Zoo. The Zoo reserves the right to determine acceptable requests and appropriate use of any content obtained on premises. All content must uphold the Zoo‚Äôs mission and respect our facilities, animals, staff, visitors, and overall Zoo image. You must make a request at least two weeks in advance so a member of the communications team can accompany you during your visit. Please contact us with specific details of your request and affiliation. Photo Shoots The Central Florida Zoo & Botanical Gardens has a variety of aesthetically desirable locations for professional photography. All photo shoots are subject to fees and must be scheduled with our events manager. If you are looking to book a photoshoot on our property, please contact our events team at 407-323-4450 ext. 103 or events@centralfloridazoo.org . Student Projects Students interested in conducting interview, photo, or video projects at the Central Florida Zoo & Botanical Gardens must request permission through the Zoo‚Äôs Communications Team. We believe in the value of education and will try to accommodate academic requests, however, depending on staff availability, not all requests can be approved. You must make a request at least two weeks in advance so a member of the communications team can accompany you during your visit. Please contact us with specific details of school, course, project, and deadline. Include requests about interviews, specific animals, etc. Freelance Writers & Social Media Influencers We are often contacted by community members looking to obtain digital content at the Central Florida Zoo & Botanical Gardens. We would like to consider all media requests that may be mutually beneficial. If you are interested in sharing your Zoo or Seminole Aerial Adventure experience with your online community or following, please contact us at least one week prior to your proposed visit and include: Topic of interest (wildlife, travel, family fun, adventure, etc.) Information about your platform including the target audience and demographics of your followers Links to your posts Number and statistics of your followers Date(s) your content will be published If your proposed content is approved, the Central Florida Zoo & Botanical Gardens will provide up to two complimentary single-day tickets¬† for use only on weekdays (Monday‚ÄìThursday). Only one request will be considered per 12-month period per writer/influencer. Use of Central Florida Zoo & Botanical Gardens for Personal Photography We encourage guests to take personal video and photographs while enjoying your visit! All photographs must be taken in public guest areas or within spaces designated for special events, programs, etc. The Central Florida Zoo & Botanical Gardens has the right to withdraw consent of use for any photograph or video and to reproduce photographs taken on grounds. Don‚Äôt forget to use #CentralFloridaZoo when posting! View Current Zoo News Here News Zoo Boo Bash, presented by Orlando Health, returns for... Central Florida Zoo & Botanical Gardens ‚Ä∫ Special Discounts There are so many ways to experience the Zoo Guests wanting to use one of the discounts listed below must purchase their tickets in person at the Zoo‚Äôs Admissions Window. Single Day Admission Discounts Military Discount ( Active duty; Current Guard/Reserve; Non-Active Duty; Retirees; and Veterans )‚Äî Receive 20% off daily admission for service member and entire party. Must show valid I.D. and present valid military I.D. or DD214. Law Enforcement and First Responders ( All Branches )‚Äî Receive 10% off general admission for yourself and entire party. Must show proper I.D. Healthcare Workers (Doctors, Nurses, and Hospital Staff )‚Äî Receive 10% off general admission for yourself and entire party. Must show proper I.D. Teachers‚Äî All public or private school instructional employees (teachers) receive 20% off general admission. Must provide copy of school/teacher ID or printout verification. College Students‚Äî Receive 10% off of a single day general admission purchase. Must show valid college or university I.D. Local Hotel Guests‚Äî Show your hotel key card to receive 10% off single day admission for your entire party. Please Note: These special discounts are only available for Zoo and Seminole Aerial Adventure single day admission tickets purchased at the Zoo‚Äôs Admission window. Reciprocal Programs View the current list of AZA-accredited facilities that participate by clicking on the current AZA Reciprocal Admissions Program List on the AZA‚Äôs website here . The Central Florida Zoo & Botanical Gardens is proud to participate in the AZA Reciprocal Admissions Program . We offer 50% off admission for up to two (2) adults and six (6) children listed on a participating AZA zoo or aquarium‚Äôs membership card. (Entry is based on the issuing facility‚Äôs valid membership card, with the above limitations.) The Central Florida Zoo & Botanical Gardens also offers reciprocal admission to annual pass holders, including: Bok Tower Gardens , Florida Clearwater Marine Aquarium , Florida Henson Robinson Zoo , Illinois Salisbury Zoo , Maryland Santa Ana Zoo , California Reciprocal admission benefits are for 50% off general admission for current annual pass holders only ( must present valid pass card from reciprocal attraction and photo I.D. ), and do not apply to guests. Discounts apply to Zoo admission only and does not apply to Seminole Aerial Adventures, train or carousel rides, education programs, special events, and cannot be combined with any other offers or discounts. Questions? Please contact the Zoo prior to your visit at 407-323-4450 News Zoo Boo Bash, presented by Orlando Health, returns for... Save up to $5 per ticket when you purchase tickets online in advance of your Zoo visit. Online tickets are valid for one year from the date of purchase. No refunds or rainchecks. Non-Peak Pricing Ticket Booth Online Adult $26.95 $21.95 Child (Ages 3 ‚Äì 12) $18.95 $16.95 Child (Ages 2 and under) Free Free Senior (Ages 55+) $22.95 $17.95 Peak Pricing Ticket Booth Online Adult $28.95 $23.95 Child (Ages 3 ‚Äì 12) $19.95 $17.95 Child (Ages 2 and under) Free Free Senior (Ages 55+) $24.95 $19.95 Peak days fall on all weekends, select holidays and other select dates throughout the year. Each individual entering the Zoo requires a ticket, including children 2 and under which are free. No discounts* are available for tickets purchased online. For online purchases, tickets will be sent to your email and can be scanned directly from your phone, via that email. By purchasing a ticket to the Zoo, you are agreeing to comply with all Zoo Rules . Parking is free. The Zoo is open daily from 9 a.m. to 4 p.m. Each order will include a $3 transaction fee to cover order processing. This fee is per charged per transaction/order and not per ticket. Purchase General Admission Tickets Please note: If you are purchasing admission tickets as a gift, the purchaser‚Äôs name and contact information will print directly on each ticket. This will not prevent the ticket from being used by the recipient. * Guests wishing to use the AZA Reciprocal Admission Discount, or another discount offered on single-day Zoo admission, must purchase their tickets at the Zoo‚Äôs Admission Window. Proper identification is required to receive a discount. Electric Vehicle Information We offer EV Chargers onsite, free of charge for visiting Zoo guests only . Violators will be towed at vehicle owner‚Äôs expense. EV drivers can download the FPL EVolution app to find and navigate to the closest FPL charging station. The app will route users to the selected station where drivers will scan a code and connect their EV to the station to begin charging. The app will also provide users with information about port availability, outages, charging history, trends, nearby amenities, and more. The Zoo‚Äôs parking lot is accessible daily from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. The charging stations are compatible with all major EV models, including those manufactured by Audi, Chevrolet, Honda, Kia, Nissan, Tesla, and Volkswagen. But we are lucky enough to have some pretty interesting humans on staff, too! If you haven‚Äôt had a chance to attend a Keeper Chat or meet one of our knowledgeable education staff members, definitely make it a point on your next visit! They have so much to share. Today, we wanted to introduce you to one of those very special Zoo staff members to give you a behind-the-scenes look at just how much goes into caring for the collection of animals at our Orlando Zoo and how to become a zoo keeper. We sat down with Christopher Torge, our Director of Animal Operations, to learn more. See what he had to say below! Question: How long have you been at the Zoo? Answer: I started February 2021, so a little over two years. Q: What was your experience before coming here? A: I have been in the zoological field since 1998. I have worked at the Central Park Zoo, Rosamond Gifford Zoo, and Disney‚Äôs Animal Kingdom and Animal Kingdom Lodge. I have been an intern, animal keeper, senior keeper, zoological manager, and now Director of Animal Operations. Q: What are some things people might not know about you and your work with animals? I‚Äôve ridden more elephants than horses. Vultures are one of my favorite animals to work with. And I have spent over 6,768 hours working with giraffes! Q: As Director of Animal Operations, what are your main job duties? A: I am responsible for our entire animal collection and the team of 30 people that take care of them. I focus on providing my team with all the tools they need to be successful at their job and to enjoy their job. I partner with all the other teams at the Zoo to provide the best possible care for our animal collection. Q: What kind of education and experience does someone need to get to your position ? A: First, I have a degree in Zoology.¬† For someone in my role, it‚Äôs also important to have experience with project management, zoological park attractions and operations, and a solid leadership style. Q: What drew you to this work to begin with? A: I‚Äôve always been fascinated with animal behavior. That naturally led to me wanting to work with them. Q: What‚Äôs your favorite thing about working at the Zoo? A: I really enjoy providing for the people on my team and watching them grow professionally. I enjoy providing new experiences for them, like exhibit design and animal training. These allow them to build on their strengths and are things that make our profession unique. Q: What‚Äôs something a visitor might not know that you want them to know? A: That a large percentage of time is spent evaluating and improving the wellbeing of our animal collection. Our staff spends hours on assessments, evaluations and behavioral husbandry to truly provide the highest level of care for our animals. Q: What‚Äôs the hardest part about your job? A: Because the staff spend so much time with the animals, they develop deep bonds with them. Watching my team have to say goodbye to an animal is always the hardest, even when it is the best and necessary decision. Q: What‚Äôs one thing people can do to help animals or further the Zoo‚Äôs mission? A: Our guests can do their part for conservation through some simple actions ! Recycle, plant a butterfly garden, donate to a conservation organization, volunteer, and spread the word to others to do the same. They all make a difference! We hope Chris has taught you something new about the Zoo or inspired you to help. After all, our mission is to create connections that inspire people to take action on behalf of wildlife! Be sure to say hi to Chris or the other Zoo staff members on your next visit. Learn more here . More News Zoo Boo Bash, presented by Orlando Health, returns for... Central Florida Zoo & Botanical Gardens ‚Ä∫ About the Zoo ‚Ä∫ Central Florida Zoological Society About the Central Florida Zoological Society A 501(c)3, non-profit education and conservation organization that operates the Central Florida Zoo & Botanical Gardens in Sanford, FL. The Zoo was founded in 1923 and enjoyed a rich & storied history in downtown Sanford, prior to moving to its current location across from Lake Monroe in the summer of 1975. Twenty-three acres of the property feature lush plantings and space dedicated to the care of the 350 animals representing over 100 species in our collection. The Central Florida Zoological Society, Inc. is governed by a 21-member Board of Trustees, chaired by Chandler Robertson of Sanford, Florida. Finances & Effectiveness: The Central Florida Zoological Society, Inc. is a smart choice for charitable giving and consistently receives high ratings from the independent rating service, Charity Navigator . The Central Florida Zoological Society, Inc. operates the Central Florida Zoo & Botanical Gardens. Contributions are tax deductible to the extent allowed by law. We strive to keep fundraising and administrative costs to a minimum, so that more of the contributions we receive can go directly to program support. Information on the Central Florida Zoological Society, Inc.‚Äôs most recently completed fiscal years, which run from July 1 through June 30, are provided below. Chamber Crush Jobs Privacy Policy Contact Us Central Florida Zoo & Botanical Gardens Welcomes New COO March 20, 2025 Member The Central Florida Zoo & Botanical Gardens is looking toward the future and strengthening its leadership team with the appointment of an industry veteran. With nearly three decades of experience in zoo operations, horticulture and conservation, Bob Chabot brings a wealth of knowledge to the role of Chief Operating Officer, particularly in Florida where he played a key part in shaping Jacksonville Zoo and Gardens. ‚ÄúWe are thrilled to welcome Bob Chabot to the Central Florida Zoo & Botanical Gardens as our new COO,‚Äù said Richard E. Glover, Jr., CEO. ‚ÄúAs we look toward the future of the Zoo, Bob‚Äôs extensive background makes him a valuable addition, and his experience will improve efficiencies and further our conservation efforts and overall guest experience.‚Äù As a respected leader in the zoological and botanical fields, Chabot brings deep-rooted experience in Florida. He spent more than a decade at Jacksonville Zoo and Gardens, where he served as Director of Horticulture, Facilities, and Exhibits from 2006 to 2017. During that time, he played a lead role in the design and execution of major construction and landscape projects, as well as special exhibits. Prior to that, Chabot served as Director of Horticulture at Jacksonville Zoo and Gardens, managing the design, installation, and maintenance of landscapes, gardens, and exhibits while leading educational tours and presentations. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm excited to bring my nearly 30 years of experience to the Central Florida Zoo & Botanical Gardens and support the critical conservation related work of the Zoo,‚Äù Chabot said. ‚ÄúI hope to build on the Zoo‚Äôs mission with storytelling in a way that inspires guests to take action on behalf of wildlife and the environment.‚Äù Chabot most recently served as Chief Operating Officer at Zoo New England, where he managed the day-to-day operations of Franklin Park Zoo in Boston and Stone Zoo in Stoneham, Massachusetts. He also previously held the role of Director of Horticulture at the New England Botanical Gardens in Providence, Rhode Island. Chabot succeeds Stephanie Williams, who retired after 25 years at the Zoo. Under Williams‚Äô leadership, the Zoo saw significant growth in guest engagement, conservation initiatives and facility improvements. In his new role with the Central Florida Zoo & Botanical Gardens, Chabot will oversee the Zoo‚Äôs daily operations and strategic initiatives aimed at advancing the Zoo‚Äôs mission of conservation and education. He will also focus on optimizing operational efficiencies and elevating the Zoo‚Äôs botanical gardens, as well as improving visitor experience. For more information about the Central Florida Zoo & Botanical Gardens, visit www.centralfloridazoo.org . To view or download Bob Chabot‚Äôs headshot, click here . About the Central Florida Zoo & Botanical Gardens The Central Florida Zoo & Botanical Gardens is home to more than 350 animals in Sanford, Florida. As a not-for-profit organization, it is a leader in conservation, creating connections that inspire people to take action for wildlife. More information is available at www.centralfloridazoo.org . Central Florida Zoo & Botanical Gardens ‚Ä∫ Visit ‚Ä∫ Location Central Florida Zoo & Botanical Gardens 3755 W. Seminole Blvd. Sanford, Florida 32771 Getting Here Orlando On I-4 , travel east to Exit 104 (HWY 17-92). Take a left off of exit ramp onto 17-92. The Zoo is 1/8 mile on the right on HWY 17-92. On the Central Florida Greenway (417) , travel north until it ends in Sanford at I-4. Head east on I-4 to Exit 104 (HWY 17-92). Take a left off the exit ramp onto 17-92. The Zoo is 1/8 mile on the right on HWY 17-92. Volusia County On I-4 , travel west to Exit 104. Exit right off the ramp onto HWY 17-92. The Zoo is 1/4 mile on the right. On HWY 17-92 , travel south through Volusia County toward Sanford. The Zoo is on the right side, just past the St. Johns River Bridge. Brevard County Take Interstate 95 to State Road 46, Exit 81 (Sanford/Mims). Travel west to Sanford. Turn right on HWY 17-92 and follow through Sanford and around the lakefront. The Zoo is two miles past the Central Florida Regional Hospital on the left. Lake County Take Highway 441 south to State Road 46. Go east on 46 to Interstate 4. Take I-4 east one exit. Exit at #104. Follow the signs to the Zoo. _______________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________ Learn more about I-4 Express and get updates here . Volunteer Internships It‚Äôs a question team members of the Central Florida Zoo & Botanical Gardens get asked most frequently: How can I get a job at the Zoo? Many people have a passion for animals, but one of the most important qualifications for a position on the Zoo team is a commitment to our mission to be an education and conservation resource providing experiences that excite and inspire children and adults to learn and act on behalf of wildlife. As a non-profit organization, the Central Florida Zoo & Botanical Gardens has many employment opportunities throughout the year in various departments including Animal Care, Education, Guest Experience, Horticulture, Facilities/Maintenance, as well as Administration. Join us at the Zoo! Thank you for your interest in a position with the Central Florida Zoo & Botanical Gardens! Please view open positions below. Please email your resume, cover letter & 3 professional references to HR@CentralFloridaZoo.org and indicate which position you are interested in. Please note that a cover letter is required for consideration . Facilities: Groundskeeper ‚Äì Full Time & Part Time Positions Available Special Opportunity for Veterinary Post-Graduates: 1-Year Veterinary Internship in Zoo Medicine Veterinary: Associate Veterinarian SSA Group Opportunities SSA Group is a third-party vendor that handles ticketing and food & beverage at the Central Florida Zoo & Botanical Gardens. SSA Staff are not employed by the Central Florida Zoo & Botanical Gardens. There are no SSA Group opportunities posted at this time. Don‚Äôt see what you‚Äôre looking for? Click here for volunteer opportunities. All other job openings will be posted to Indeed or the Association of Zoos & Aquariums (AZA). Please visit those sites for information on employment opportunities. How do I apply? Applications should be submitted as directed for each open position. Follow-up calls are not accepted. The Central Florida Zoo & Botanical Gardens and the Orianne Center for Indigo Conservation are operated by the Central Florida Zoological Society, Inc. (CFZS), a 501(c)3 non-profit organization. We are an Equal Opportunity Employer and a Drug-Free Workplace. A pre-employment drug test will be performed. Equal Employment Opportunity The Central Florida Zoological Society is an equal opportunity employer and makes decisions related to compensation and all terms, conditions, or privileges of employment on the basis of merit. Company policy prohibits unlawful discrimination based on race, color, creed, sex (including pregnancy), gender orientation, religion, marital status, age, national origin or ancestry, physical or mental disability, medical condition, genetic characteristic, military status, or any other consideration made unlawful by federal, state or local laws. Contact Us to Host Your Event at the Zoo Host your group at the Wayne M. Densch Discovery Center at the Central Florida Zoo & Botanical Gardens. This versatile event space features an outdoor courtyard, covered porch, and a 3,400 square foot banquet hall. You can also enjoy your function immersed in natural surroundings at the Rainforest Pavilion. This private, covered facility has seating for up to 200, a kitchenette, private restrooms, and plenty of space for games and activities. It is available from February 1 ‚Äì October 10 of each year. Come see us! Site visits are available 7 days a week. For more information, send an email to events@centralfloridazoo.org or call 407-323-4450 ext. 103. Corporate Meetings and Functions Whether your group is 25 or 200, the Central Florida Zoo & Botanical Gardens has the space and equipment you need to host the perfect meeting, staff retreat, holiday party, or company picnic. In addition to the space, we also offer audio visual and projection equipment, a stage, and other add-ons to meet all of your event needs. We do the heavy lifting! The room is set up by our incredible staff so that you can focus on your program and guests. Weddings Located in Sanford, Florida, the Central Florida Zoo & Botanical Gardens is ideally situated close to Orlando‚Äôs main attractions, and is adjacent to I-4 for ease of travel and transportation. We have many different venue spaces to suit weddings of any style. We offer both indoor and outdoor ceremonies, a reception space, as well as small wedding spaces. The possibilities are endless here, and the Zoo‚Äôs natural surroundings make for beautiful and unique photography. Our events team is here to make sure your special day goes smoothly, and our caterers are fully versed in delighting everyone‚Äôs taste buds. Let us help create your happy ending when you say ‚ÄúI Do‚Äù at the Central Florida Zoo! Social Events Your family, friends, and employees will have the time of their lives when you invite them to our Zoo for your life celebrations, company picnics, and family reunions. We have the ideal menus to provide your social event a delicious touch, and all sorts of fun things for people of all ages to indulge in. Our inside spaces and outdoor spaces will suit your needs any time of year. Group rates, scavenger hunts, giraffe feedings, and much more will give your guests a memorable experience they‚Äôll be eager to repeat. Come have fun with us at the Central Florida Zoo! Venues The Wayne M. Densch Discovery Center is home to our Safari Room, a large banquet hall perfect for parties or corporate meetings. Attached to that space is our beautiful, rustic covered porch, perfect for mingling or a hosted bar. Just past the porch you‚Äôll see our Gazebo Courtyard. This space is surrounded by lush, seasonal flowers and greenery, making it the ideal location for a wedding ceremony. Inside the lobby you‚Äôll find our Insect Zoo; with a hair-raising ambiance, any event held here will be unforgettable. Dimming lights, staging, cocktail tables, and more are set up by our event staff so that you can focus on having fun! The Rainforest Pavilion is tucked away under our magnificent canopy of trees near the front of the property. It is fully covered, and our large trees keep the space shaded and cool year-round. With nearby parking and plenty of outdoor space, this is the perfect venue for a company picnic or family event, giving you access to private restrooms and a kitchenette.
